questions.question: What is Android?
questions.details: Android is a stack of software for mobile devices which includes an Operating System, middleware and some key applications. The application executes within its own process and its own instance of Dalvik Virtual Machine.
questions.shortAns: A stack of software for mobile devices.

questions.question: What is a Service?
questions.details: Android service is a component that is used to perform operations on the background such as playing music, handle network transactions, interacting content providers etc.
questions.shortAns: It performs background functionalities.

questions.question: What is the APK format?
questions.details: The Android packaging key is compressed with classes, UI's, supportive assets and manifest. All files are compressed to a single file that is called the APK.
questions.shortAns: It is compressed with classes, UI's, supportive assets and manifest.

questions.question: What is an intent?
questions.details: It is connected to either the external world of application or internal world of application, Such as, opening a pdf is an intent and connect to the web browser, etc.
questions.shortAns: It is a declaration to do something.

questions.question: What is an android manifest file?
questions.details: Every application must have an AndroidManifest.xml file (with precisely that name) in its root directory. The manifest file presents essential information about your app to the Android system, information the system must have before it can run any of the app's code.
questions.shortAns: It is a resource file which contains all the details needed by the android system about the application.

questions.question: What is AAPT?
questions.details: AAPT is short for Android Asset Packaging Tool. This tool provides developers with the ability to deal with zip-compatible archives, which includes creating, extracting as well as viewing its contents. This tool allows you to view, create, and update Zip-compatible archives (zip, jar, apk). It can also compile resources into binary assets.
questions.shortAns: It is a packaging tool and is included in the tools directory of the SDK.

questions.question: What is an activity?
questions.details: Activities are what you refer to as the window to a user interface. Just as you create windows in order to display output or to ask for an input in the form of dialog boxes, activities play the same role, though it may not always be in the form of a user interface.
questions.shortAns: It is the window to a user interface.

questions.question: What is an Intent?
questions.details: Intents displays notification messages to the user from within the Android enabled device. It can be used to alert the user of a particular state that occurred. Users can be made to respond to intents.
questions.shortAns: it displays a notification message to the user from within the Android enabled device.

questions.question: What is a container?
questions.details: Containers, as the name itself implies, holds objects and widgets together, depending on which specific items are needed and in what particular arrangement that is wanted. Containers may hold labels, fields, buttons, or even child containers, as examples.
questions.shortAns: It holds objects and widgets together.

questions.question: What is Orientation?
questions.details: Orientation, which can be set using setOrientation(), dictates if the LinearLayout is represented as a row or as a column. Values are set as either HORIZONTAL or VERTICAL. As with almost all smartphones, Android supports two screen orientations: portrait and landscape. When the screen orientation of an Android device is changed, the current activity being displayed is destroyed and re-created automatically to redraw its content in the new orientation
questions.shortAns: It dictates if the LinearLayout is represented as a row or as a column.

questions.question: What is adb?
questions.details: Adb is short for Android Debug Bridge. It allows developers the power to execute remote shell commands. Its basic function is to allow and control communication towards and from the emulator port.
questions.shortAns: It allows developers the power to execute remote shell commands.

questions.question: What is an intent filter?
questions.details: Because every component needs to indicate which intents they can respond to, intent filters are used to filter out intents that these components are willing to receive. One or more intent filters are possible, depending on the services and activities that is going to make use of it.
questions.shortAns: It specifies the types of intents to which an activity, service, or broadcast receiver can respond to.

questions.question: What is an intent filter?
questions.details: An intent filter specifies the types of intents to which an activity, service, or broadcast receiver can respond to by declaring the capabilities of a component. Android components register intent filters either statically in the AndroidManifest. xml or in case of a broadcast receiver also dynamically via code.
questions.shortAns: It declares the capabilities of its parent component.

questions.question: What is a Fragment?
questions.details: A fragment is a part or portion of an activity. It is modular in a sense that you can move around or combine with other fragments in a single activity. Fragments are also reusable.
questions.shortAns: It is a part or portion of an activity.

questions.question: What is a Sticky Intent?
questions.details: A Sticky Intent is a broadcast from sendStickyBroadcast() method such that the intent floats around even after the broadcast, allowing others to collect data from it.
questions.shortAns: It is an intent that can send or recieve messages after the application has closed.

questions.question: What is an action?
questions.details: In Android development, an action is what the intent sender wants to do or expected to get as a response. Most application functionality is based on the intended action.
questions.shortAns: It is what the intent sender wants to do or expected to get as a response.

questions.question: What is a nine-patch image?
questions.details: In general, a Nine-patch image allows resizing that can be used as background or other image size requirements for the target device. The Nine-patch refers to the way you can resize the image: 4 corners that are unscaled, 4 edges that are scaled in 1 axis, and the middle one that can be scaled into both axes.
questions.shortAns: it allows the creation of custom graphics that will scale the way that you define

questions.question: What is application?
questions.details: Application class is a base class within an Android application, that comprises of different components such as Activity, Service, Broadcast Receivers & Content Providers. These components communicate with each other with the help of Intents, Callbacks & other methods. Often, components depend on other components, for eg: initiating an activity on a button click.
questions.shortAns: It is the base class within an Android app that contains all other components such as activities and services.

questions.question: What is application?
questions.details: Application class is a base class within an Android application, that comprises of different components such as Activity, Service, Broadcast Receivers & Content Providers. These components communicate with each other with the help of Intents, Callbacks & other methods. Often, components depend on other components, for eg: initiating an activity on a button click.
questions.shortAns: It is instantiated before any other class when the process for your application/package is created.

questions.question: What is the Context?
questions.details: A Context is a handle to the system; it provides services like resolving resources, obtaining access to databases and preferences, and so on. An Android app has activities. Context is like a handle to the environment your application is currently running in.
questions.shortAns: It is a handle to the environment your application is currently running in.

questions.question: What is the Context?
questions.details: A Context is a handle to the system; it provides services like resolving resources, obtaining access to databases and preferences, and so on. An Android app has activities. Context is like a handle to the environment your application is currently running in.
questions.shortAns: It is the base class for Activity, Service, Application, etc.

questions.question: What is Armv7?
questions.details: There are 3 CPU architectures in Android. ARMv7 is the most common as it is optimised for battery consumption. ARM64 is an evolved version of that that supports 64-bit processing for more powerful computing. ARMx86, is the least used for these three, since it is not battery friendly. It is more powerful than the other two.
questions.shortAns: It is the most common CPU architecture in android.

questions.question: What is a content provider?
questions.details: A ContentProvider provides data from one application to another, when requested. It manages access to a structured set of data. It provides mechanisms for defining data security. ContentProvider is the standard interface that connects data in one process with code running in another process.
questions.shortAns: It is the standard interface that connects data in one process with code running in another process.

questions.question: What is a thread?
questions.details: Thread should be used to separate long running operations from main thread so that performance is improved. But it can’t be cancelled elegantly and it can’t handle configuration changes of Android. You can’t update UI from Thread.
questions.shortAns: It is used to separate long running operations from the main thread.

questions.question: What is an AsyncTask?
questions.details: With AsyncTask, you can update UI unlike java Thread. But many long running tasks will choke the performance.
questions.shortAns: It is used to handle work items shorter than 5ms in duration.

questions.question: What is a thread?
questions.details: Threads are generic processing tasks that can do most things, but one thing they cannot do is update the UI.
questions.shortAns: It is a thread of execution in a program.

questions.question: What is a handler?
questions.details: Each Handler instance is associated with a single thread and that thread's message queue. They are not threads in their own behalf.
questions.shortAns: It is bound to the thread and allows for communication with the UI thread.

questions.question: What is a handler?
questions.details: A Handler object receives messages and runs code to handle the messages. With handlers you can also have things like MessageQueuing, scheduling and repeating.
questions.shortAns: is part of the Android system's framework for managing threads.

questions.question: What is an AsyncTask?
questions.details: AsyncTask is used to perform the heavy tasks in background on a dedicated thread and pass the results back to the UI thread. Hence use of AsyncTask in android application keeps the UI thread responsive at all times.
questions.shortAns: It is an abstract Android class which helps the Android applications to handle the Main UI thread in an efficient way.

questions.question: What is an AsyncTask?
questions.details: AsyncTask is used to perform the heavy tasks in background on a dedicated thread and pass the results back to the UI thread. Hence use of AsyncTask in android application keeps the UI thread responsive at all times.
questions.shortAns: It allows us to perform long lasting tasks/background operations and show the result on the UI thread without affecting the main thread.

questions.question: What is a handler?
questions.details: Handlers are objects for managing threads. Handlers allow communicating between the background thread and the main thread. They run outside of the activity’s lifecycle, so they need to be cleaned up properly or else you will have thread leaks.
questions.shortAns: It receives messages and writes code on how to handle the message.
